contentrichtext.text: {{refimprove|date=December 2010}} '''John Bradley Gambling''' (April 9, 1897 – November 21, 1974) was an [[United States|American]] radio personality. He was a member of the [[The Gambling family]], 3 generations of whom - John B., [[John A. Gambling|John A.]] and [[John R. Gambling|John R.]] - were hosts of [[WOR (AM)|WOR]] Radio's ([[New York City]], 710 AM) morning show ''[[Rambling with Gambling]]'' (now known as ''The John Gambling Show'') over the course of over 75 years (1925–2000 and 2008–present). John B. was the host from 1925 to 1959, when he retired in favor of his son, [[John A. Gambling]]. With his Musical Clock, his all-in-fun setting-up exercises, cheerio music, wheezy gags, weather information and news scraps, John B. Gambling was a WOR fixture. Once he was a British seaman on a World War I mine sweeper.<ref>''[[Time Magazine]]'', March 18, 1940</ref> John Gambling had a band, and provided live music, including the March of the Seven Dwarfs every morning at 7 am sharp. Gambling bought a home in [[Teaneck, New Jersey]] in 1929.<ref>Staff. [http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50B1EF73B5C177A93C3AB178CD85F4D8285F9 "MANY HOMES ARE SOLD IN TEANECK SECTION; $3,000,000 Palisades Acreage Reported Acquired by Syndicate."], ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 1, 1929. Accessed December 13, 2011.</ref><ref>Taylor, Mildred. [http://www.teaneck.org/virtualvillage/Religious/index.html "Spiritual Comforts Take Root"], ''History of Teaneck'', pp. 98-103 via Teaneck Public Library. Accessed December 13, 2011. "Mane{{sic}} good people came to live in the township, among them Ferde Grofe, composer of "The Grand Canyon Suite" and other fine music. The senior John Gambling of Radio Station WOR lived in Teaneck with his wife and his son John, who now heads the program that keeps the area posted each morning.
